title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Eligibility is based on receiving certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance program or being between 55 and 64 receiving PBGC payments. The Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. Workers must petition the U.S. Department of Labor to establish their job loss was due to a qualified cause. If confirmed, they are eligible for TAA benefits, including the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) if they receive Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA). TRA is a cash payment for workers in TAA-sponsored training, while RTAA is a wage supplement for older workers who secure qualified employment at a lower wage. RTAA is a wage supplement for workers aged 50 and older who were certified for TAA and secure qualified employment at a lower wage. It pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years, with a maximum benefit of $10,000. ATAA is a similar wage-insurance program that existed before the recent TAA reauthorization. Eligibility for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is limited to individuals receiving TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. PBGC benefits are available to individuals who worked for a firm with an insured defined-benefit pension plan taken over by the PBGC. The PBGC assumes control of defined-benefit plans to protect participants' interests or if employers demonstrate financial need. They use plan assets and insurance reserves to pay pensions to former workers. Those receiving PBGC-paid pensions may be eligible for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old and not yet on Medicare. Eligibility for the HCTC has limitations, excluding those with employer-sponsored health plans, Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, or CHIP. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must not be eligible for Medicare Part A, Tricare, be incarcerated, or claimed as a dependent. The HCTC can be used for health insurance covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Family members have the same eligibility restrictions as the taxpayer and can receive the HCTC for up to two years after specific events. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can be claimed by eligible taxpayers to cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance. There are 11 categories of coverage, with four being automatically qualified health plans and seven being state-qualified health plans. Options include COBRA coverage, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by a VEBA. State-qualified health plans can only be chosen if the state has established them. State-qualified health plans can be chosen by eligible individuals if their state has established these options, which include coverage under state laws, state high-risk pools, plans for state employees, and other state-operated plans. These plans must provide four consumer protections and are available to HCTC-eligible individuals with prior creditable coverage and no significant breaks in coverage. State-qualified health plans offer guaranteed issue coverage without denial based on preexisting conditions, equal premiums for qualifying individuals, and benefits comparable to others. Certain types of coverage are not considered qualified health insurance. The HCTC program, administered by the IRS, involves multiple federal and state agencies. The Treasury handles advance payments, the IRS reviews tax returns, and DOL and PBGC help identify eligible individuals. State entities like SWAs and health agencies also play a role in providing information about benefits like the HCTC. The HCTC program involves multiple federal and state agencies, including the departments of insurance and health agencies. SWAs and PBGC help identify eligible individuals, with the IRS mailing program kits to eligible taxpayers. Taxpayers can claim the credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Other tax credits do not affect HCTC eligibility. The HCTC program allows eligible individuals to claim the credit when filing tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. Taxpayers must complete Form 8885 and provide proof of payment for qualified health insurance to claim the credit. The credit amount can reduce taxes owed and is refundable if it exceeds the tax liability. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can be used to reduce taxes owed by taxpayers. It is refundable, so any excess amount is given to the taxpayer as a tax refund. To receive advance payments, individuals must register with the HCTC program and be enrolled in a qualified health insurance plan. Payments are made to Treasury for the monthly premium, with 27.5% paid by the individual and 72.5% by Treasury, which is then sent to the health insurance plans.
